utterances: Rewrite history a little bit.
well, actually, yeah, nominate all the judges then he rewrote history and so they declare it as a coup so there was, you know, those kind of things did happen in Venezuela.

I'm Neal Conan in Washington.

Today, we're about to get to the TALK OF THE NATION Opinion Page, but first, we'll wrap up our conversation about Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez, the man whose every musing means like a provocative op-ed.
Our guest is Chavez biographer, Bart Jones.
His book is called ""Hugo!"" And we're taking your calls and e-mail questions.
Our phone number is 800-989-8255.
E-mail, talk@npr.org.
Let's go to Brad.
Brad's on the line with us from Des Moines in Iowa.
Hi.
Thank you for taking my call.
Sure.
My question is concerning specifically Hugo Chavez's relationship with the leaders of mainly Iran but also Syria, specifically dealing with his relationship with the president of Iran.

I'm wondering if you could give insight as to what his political motivations might be for that relationship considering that the president of Iran as popularity problems not only abroad but also, you know, amongst his own people at home.
He's not seen as being, you know, the sort of the - he's not seen as being very politically strong even at home.
So I was wondering if you could help me understand as to why he feels this is a good relationship for him.
Bart Jones?
Well, I think the basic answer is oil.
Iran was a founding member also of OPEC as Venezuela was.
And this is not a new relationship.
Venezuela has had relationships with these Middle Eastern countries for decades as has the United States.
We are friends with Saudi Arabia, which I think hardly anyone would classify as a democracy.
So these are, you know, kind of, you know, real world political relationships that the job is like other leaders have entered into, you know, is…
Syria is not an oil producer.
Excuse me?
Syria is not an oil producer.
No.
But of these controversial countries that he's involved with are, and you know, does he need to flaunt this relationship?
Is that a smart idea politically?
You know, even some of his allies would argue it's not.
But this is part of the reason that he's entered into these relationships.
Also, he's looking for allies anywhere he can find them pretty much.
The United States government has essentially declared war on Chavez.
They supported the 2002 coup against him, a coup, by the way during which Chavez was, by his account, almost executed.
So he feels that the United Sates government, the Bush administration, we should say, is really out to have him overthrown pretty much.
And he is going to look for allies anywhere he can get it.
Sometimes among unsafely regimes, you know?
No doubt about it.
But, you know, the U.S.
itself and other countries have done the same type of thing at times as well.
All right, thank you very much.
Thanks for the call, Brad.

And finally, do you think that he will - we've spoken of his admiration for Fidel Castro among other things - do you think that he will appropriate the cult of personality that so many leftist presidents have used in other countries?
well, you know, it's certainly a danger, Neal, and that's one thing that people have to look for.
You know, Chavez's movement clearly is too much dependent on Hugo Chavez.
There's a real feeling that if he disappeared tomorrow, the whole movement might collapse, so he needs to diversify his leadership.
I think that's one of the lessons that the people have given him with this defeat that he suffered last December.
They need to find new leaders in his movement.
No one from the FAA would speak on air for this story.

But in a filing in response to an appeals court ruling, Dorenda Baker, the FAA's head of aviation safety, cites no evidence that smaller seats, larger passengers and less room between rows, quote, ""hamper the speed of passenger evacuation."" But that ruling isn't sitting well with many airline passengers.
Paul Hudson is with the group Flyers Rights.
Well, it's really become almost like a torture class.
I did want to just comment too on the television station issue that which folks have spoken about.
Once again, we kind of heard a very simplistic version of that, Chavez shut them down because they we criticizing him.
Well, it's a little more complex than that.
Radio Caracas Television took part in the 2002 coup against Hugo Chavez.
They basically help try to have him overthrown.
And one thing they did was there was a new blackout in Venezuela after he was kidnapped for two days and went missing, when his supporters took to the streets to demand that he be returned.
There was no news on television for two days.
So in the case of Radio Caracas television, it goes, a little beyond them simply criticizing the president.
It goes to them really trying to overthrow a democratically elected president.
So again, the situation is a little bit more complex in Venezuela than folks who've sometimes been led to believe, I think.
Bart Jones, thanks for your time today.
I appreciate it.
Thank you Neal.
Bart Jones, the author of ""Hugo!"" a biography of Hugo Chavez and he was with us today from WRAQ in Hempstead in New York.
SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Ira Flatow.
We're a few minutes between Park Heights and Falls(ph) and then again between York and Delaney Valley according to another driver.
And we're do have some heavy traffic out along the bottom into the JFX from an earlier crash…
This may sound like a traffic report, but it's actually - could be the sound of a radio revolution, a radio unlike any other.
It does not use standard parts made out of silicon semiconductors and transistors.
This is a radio made out of carbon nanotube electronics, and is described last week in an article in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
This transistor radio based on carbon nanotubes is so small that all of the active parts would fit on the head of a pin.
Now, the point of the work is not to build a tiny radio this small, though it certainly could have practical applications.
The real point is to demonstrate something.
It's a demonstration of carbon-based electronics - carbon-based transistors, carbon-based semiconductors.
A field some researchers say will be the next thing after the silicon revolution of our last generation, moving toward carbon-based electronics.
John Rogers is a professor in the department of material science and engineering at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign.
He is one of the authors of the paper in the public - National Academy of Sciences, proceedings there.
And he joins us by phone from Urbana.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Thanks.
It's a pleasure to be on the show.
How small is this radio?
I mean, you have to have a way to plug into it, right?
It's got to have some bigger part to it.
Oh, well, in a way that's true.
I mean, the active materials are of course carbon nanotubes and they're truly nanoscale in their dimensions.
They have diameters that are comparable to the size of medium-sized molecule.
They're pretty long, though.
And the devices that you build with them are quite a bit larger also because they involve electrodes and dialectrics(ph) and other components.
So there's a range of size scales involved in the devices.
And then, you know, several of those devices are assembled together to make the radio.
So your previous comment that the, you know, all the active devices could fit on the heads of a pin is absolutely true.
The active components are quite a bit smaller.
But, you know, when you think about a radio, you got to have an antenna.
And for AMS and bands, those antennas are really going to determine the overall size, scale of the system.
And, you know, together with the fact that you have to plug headphones in or plug them into a speaker to listen to them, those kinds of, you know, more conventional components...
Yeah.
...set the overall scale of the system.
So you got to go to RadioShack to get some of these parts?
Oh, well, yeah.
Actually, this is actually what we did quite literally.
I mean, we're focused on the nanotube transistors themselves in showing that we could make amplifiers with gain and mixers and filters and so on.

But the radio that we demonstrated, because, you know, we weren't focused on building a new kind of radio per se or a nanoscale radio, we actually assembled the other components of the, you know, final device, the resistors, capacitors, inductors, using a breadboard that we obtained at RadioShack.
So it's, you know, maybe three inches by three inches, the whole thing assembled on that breadboard.
Mm-hmm.
Well, so this is the first demonstration of using nanotubes for the semiconductor parts?
So - a couple of things need to be said about that.
So I think you're accurate.
This is the first nanotube transistor radio.
The area of nanotubes is a highly competitive field.
There are many groups worldwide that are working on nanotubes and trying to integrate them into electronics.
And there were two other nanotube radio demonstrations where the nanotubes are implemented as individual tubes, as sort of passive oscillator elements to make a radio.
